title: Authors and Citation

code: @Manual{,   title = {datatriage: Create Reproducible Data Cleaning Workflows},   author = {Tobias Tekath},   year = {2026},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000},   url = {https://github.com/TobiTekath/datatriage}, }

title: Create Reproducible Data Cleaning Workflows
text: goal datatriage help users create reproducible data cleaning workflows. provides functions automate data type validation detect inconsistencies data cleaning workflows.

title: Create Reproducible Data Cleaning Workflows
text: can install development version datatriage like :
code: # using pak pak::pak("TobiTekath/datatriage")  #using remotes remotes::install_github("TobiTekath/datatriage")

what: Convert given decimal character to dot — all_decimal_points_to_dot
title: Convert given decimal character to dot — all_decimal_points_to_dot
text: Convert specified decimal character numeric-like character dot.

title: Convert given decimal character to dot — all_decimal_points_to_dot
code: all_decimal_points_to_dot(df, convert_decimal_character = ",", trim_ws = FALSE)

title: Convert given decimal character to dot — all_decimal_points_to_dot
text: df data.frame tibble. convert_decimal_character Specify decimal point character shall converted dot. trim_ws Trim white space ends trying conversion?

title: Convert given decimal character to dot — all_decimal_points_to_dot
text: similar object df, potentially replaced decimal characters.

title: Convert given decimal character to dot — all_decimal_points_to_dot
text: safeguards convert numeric-like characters - non-numeric character prevent conversion.

title: Convert given decimal character to dot — all_decimal_points_to_dot
code: df <- data.frame(x1 = c("1,1", "2,2", " 3,3", "4,4 ", "1,1a")) df #>     x1 #> 1  1,1 #> 2  2,2 #> 3  3,3 #> 4 4,4  #> 5 1,1a  all_decimal_points_to_dot(df) #> Loading required namespace: testthat #>     x1 #> 1  1.1 #> 2  2.2 #> 3  3,3 #> 4 4,4  #> 5 1,1a  # also trim white space all_decimal_points_to_dot(df, trim_ws = TRUE) #>     x1 #> 1  1.1 #> 2  2.2 #> 3  3.3 #> 4  4.4 #> 5 1,1a

what: Convert all columns to character — all_to_character
title: Convert all columns to character — all_to_character

title: Convert all columns to character — all_to_character
code: all_to_character(df)

title: Convert all columns to character — all_to_character
text: df data.frame tibble columns shall converted.

title: Convert all columns to character — all_to_character
text: similar object df, columns class character().

title: Convert all columns to character — all_to_character
code: df <- data.frame(a = c(1, 2, 3), b = c("a", "b", "c")) df #>   a b #> 1 1 a #> 2 2 b #> 3 3 c  all_to_character(df) #>   a b #> 1 1 a #> 2 2 b #> 3 3 c

what: Apply a function itemwise to two vectors — apply_rowwise
title: Apply a function itemwise to two vectors — apply_rowwise
text: Apply function rowwise two length vectors, e.g. comparison functions. Optionally apply wrap functions item apply function. Functions can also function names (e.g. "sum" "+").

title: Apply a function itemwise to two vectors — apply_rowwise
code: apply_rowwise(   vec1,   vec2,   apply_fun,   wrap_fun_vec1 = NULL,   wrap_fun_vec2 = NULL )

title: Apply a function itemwise to two vectors — apply_rowwise
text: vec1 Atomic vector 1. vec2 Atomic vector 2. apply_fun function applied elements vec1 vec2 index. Can function function name. wrap_fun_vec1 Optionally, function shall applied every vec1 element applying apply_fun. Can function function name. wrap_fun_vec2 Optioanlly, function shall applied every vec2 element applying apply_fun. Can function function name.

title: Apply a function itemwise to two vectors — apply_rowwise
text: result length input vectors.

title: Apply a function itemwise to two vectors — apply_rowwise
code: # Can be useful for comparing vectors of potentially different data types. vec1 <- c(1:5) vec2 <- c(0:2, "a", "b")  apply_rowwise(vec1, vec2, apply_fun = ">", wrap_fun_vec2 = try_numeric) #> [1]  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE FALSE FALSE

what: A general vectorised switch() that keeps unaffected values — case_modify
title: A general vectorised switch() that keeps unaffected values — case_modify
text: convenience wrapper around dplyr::case_match(), .default set input parameter .x (.e. keeping values unaffected switch statements )

title: A general vectorised switch() that keeps unaffected values — case_modify
code: case_modify(.x, ...)

title: A general vectorised switch() that keeps unaffected values — case_modify
text: .x vector match . ... <dynamic-dots> sequence two-sided formulas: old_values ~ new_value. right hand side (RHS) determines output value values .x match left hand side (LHS). LHS must evaluate type vector .x. can length, allowing map multiple .x values RHS value. value repeated LHS, .e. value .x matches multiple cases, first match used. RHS inputs coerced common type. RHS input recycled size .x.

title: A general vectorised switch() that keeps unaffected values — case_modify
text: vector size .x.

title: A general vectorised switch() that keeps unaffected values — case_modify
code: dummy_df <- data.frame("a" = c(1:3)) dummy_df #>   a #> 1 1 #> 2 2 #> 3 3  # only replace 3 by 4, keep the rest dplyr::mutate(dummy_df, a = case_modify(a, 3 ~ 4)) #>   a #> 1 1 #> 2 2 #> 3 4

what: case_when variant that pastes results of matched formulas. — case_when_paste
title: case_when variant that pastes results of matched formulas. — case_when_paste
text: Drop-replacement case_when(), want combined output provided formulas. Evaluates formula separately, combines result per entry. Drops NA results pasting - NA supplied .default necessary.

title: case_when variant that pastes results of matched formulas. — case_when_paste
code: case_when_paste(..., .default = "", .sep = "")

title: case_when variant that pastes results of matched formulas. — case_when_paste
text: ... <dynamic-dots> sequence two-sided formulas. left hand side (LHS) determines values match case. right hand side (RHS) provides replacement value. LHS inputs must evaluate logical vectors. RHS inputs coerced common type. inputs recycled common size. said, encourage LHS inputs size. Recycling mainly useful RHS inputs, might supply size 1 input recycled size LHS inputs. NULL inputs ignored. .default value used LHS inputs return either FALSE NA. .default must size 1 size common size computed .... .default participates computation common type RHS inputs. NA values LHS conditions treated like FALSE, meaning result locations assigned .default value. handle missing values conditions differently, must explicitly catch another condition fall .default. typically involves variation .na(x) ~ value tailored usage case_when(). NULL, default, missing value used. .sep string separator different results combined.

title: case_when variant that pastes results of matched formulas. — case_when_paste
text: vector size inputs.

title: case_when variant that pastes results of matched formulas. — case_when_paste
code: x <- data.frame(a = c(1, 2, 3), b = c(1, 2, 4)) x #>   a b #> 1 1 1 #> 2 2 2 #> 3 3 4  dplyr::mutate(x,   class = case_when_paste(     a == b ~ "equal",     a == 1 ~ "special",     .default = "not equal",     .sep = " - "   ) ) #>   a b           class #> 1 1 1 equal - special #> 2 2 2           equal #> 3 3 4       not equal

title: Check for trailing elements — check_trailing
text: Check provided vector consistently trailing element. certain trailing value reached, subsequent vector elements value.

title: Check for trailing elements — check_trailing
code: check_trailing(vec, trail_value)

title: Check for trailing elements — check_trailing
text: vec --checked vector. trail_value trailing value check .

title: Check for trailing elements — check_trailing
text: single logical provided trailing fulfilled.

title: Check for trailing elements — check_trailing
text: trailing value occur vector, returns TRUE.

title: Check for trailing elements — check_trailing
code: # 3 is trailing vec <- c(1, 2, 3, 3, 3) check_trailing(vec, trail_value = 3) #> [1] TRUE  # c is not trailing (interrupted by b) vec <- c("b", "c", "b", "c", "c") check_trailing(vec, trail_value = "c") #> [1] FALSE  # trailing value does not occur - trailing rule is not violated check_trailing(vec, trail_value = "d") #> [1] TRUE  # also works with NA check_trailing(c(1, NA, NA), trail_value = NA) #> [1] TRUE

what: Check rowwise for trailing elements — check_trailing_rowwise
title: Check rowwise for trailing elements — check_trailing_rowwise
text: Check rowwise provided data.frame columns value trailing.

title: Check rowwise for trailing elements — check_trailing_rowwise
code: check_trailing_rowwise(df, cols, trail_value)

title: Check rowwise for trailing elements — check_trailing_rowwise
text: df data.frame tibble. cols columns df shall checked rowwise? trail_value trailing value check ?

title: Check rowwise for trailing elements — check_trailing_rowwise
text: logical vector size df rows.

title: Check rowwise for trailing elements — check_trailing_rowwise
code: df <- data.frame(a = c(1, 2, 3), b = c(2, 3, 2), c = c(3, 3, 3)) df #>   a b c #> 1 1 2 3 #> 2 2 3 3 #> 3 3 2 3  # check over all columns rowwise for trailing 3s check_trailing_rowwise(df, cols = colnames(df), trail_value = 3) #> [1]  TRUE  TRUE FALSE

what: Find not-fitting element (culprit) in vector — find_culprit
title: Find not-fitting element (culprit) in vector — find_culprit
text: Find element(s) vector, whose data type potentially deviates majority data type specified one.

title: Find not-fitting element (culprit) in vector — find_culprit
code: find_culprit(   vec,   should_be = c("majority", "numeric", "double", "integer", "character", "logical"),   return_index = FALSE,   na.rm = TRUE,   verbose = TRUE,   ... )

title: Find not-fitting element (culprit) in vector — find_culprit
text: vec Data vector find -fitting element . should_be Expected data type vec. Numeric indifferent double integer provided. set majority, expect data type elements. return_index Return index culprit elements rather value. na.rm treat NA values culprits, .e. discard culprit return. verbose guessed data type printed should_be majority. ... Arguments passed readr::guess_parser na Character vector strings interpret missing values. Set option character() indicate missing values. locale locale controls defaults vary place place. default locale US-centric (like R), can use locale() create locale controls things like default time zone, encoding, decimal mark, big mark, day/month names.

title: Find not-fitting element (culprit) in vector — find_culprit
text: named vector, either element values (default) index (return_index) guessed data types names.

title: Find not-fitting element (culprit) in vector — find_culprit
text: function can used find culprit element, prevents clean data type conversion. Utilizes readr::guess_parser() guess type every vector element. User can specify data type vector should_be, simply rely majority guess. default differentiate double integer values. Set should_be integer enforce differentiation. Ties majority guess resolved lexicographically data type name, .e. character > double > integer > logical. should_be numeric, data type interpreted double lexicographic sorting.

title: Find not-fitting element (culprit) in vector — find_culprit
code: long_data <- c(1, 2.2, "4,", 5) long_data #> [1] "1"   "2.2" "4,"  "5"    # standard type conversion would convert "4," to NA and give a warning suppressWarnings(as.numeric(long_data)) #> [1] 1.0 2.2  NA 5.0   # better for maximizing information content: find culprit element and treat it appropriately find_culprit(long_data, should_be = "numeric") #> number  #>   "4,"  as.numeric(gsub(",", "", long_data)) #> [1] 1.0 2.2 4.0 5.0

what: Move specific values to other column — move_row_values
title: Move specific values to other column — move_row_values
text: Move specific values data.frame tibble column(s). Specify rows shall affected either providing row indices logical vector select_rows. column name can also supplied select_rows, matching values rows supplied select_rows_values. possible specify one from_col to_col - always number columns. Moved values from_col replaced clear_value.

title: Move specific values to other column — move_row_values
code: move_row_values(   df,   select_rows = colnames(df)[1],   select_rows_values = NULL,   from_col,   to_col,   clear_value = NA )

title: Move specific values to other column — move_row_values
text: df data.frame tibble. select_rows rows df shall selected moving? Can indices, logical values column name df. select_rows_values column name supplied select_rows, specify column values rows want select. from_col columns df shall values selected entries moved? to_col columns df shall values selected entries moved? clear_value value shall moved values from_col replaced?

title: Move specific values to other column — move_row_values
text: object shape class df.

title: Move specific values to other column — move_row_values
code: df <- data.frame(   "id" = letters[1:5], "a" = c(5:1), "b" = c(5:4, NA, 2:1),   "c" = c(1:5), "d" = c(1:2, 2, 4:5) ) df #>   id a  b c d #> 1  a 5  5 1 1 #> 2  b 4  4 2 2 #> 3  c 3 NA 3 2 #> 4  d 2  2 4 4 #> 5  e 1  1 5 5  # move for row 3, column a to b - replace with NA df_mov <- move_row_values(df, select_rows = 3, from_col = "a", to_col = "b", clear_value = NA) df_mov #>   id  a b c d #> 1  a  5 5 1 1 #> 2  b  4 4 2 2 #> 3  c NA 3 3 2 #> 4  d  2 2 4 4 #> 5  e  1 1 5 5  # move multiple columns and rows df_mov <- move_row_values(df,   select_rows = "id", select_rows_values = c("c", "d"),   from_col = c("a", "c"), to_col = c("b", "d"), clear_value = 3 ) df_mov #>   id a b c d #> 1  a 5 5 1 1 #> 2  b 4 4 2 2 #> 3  c 3 3 3 3 #> 4  d 3 2 3 4 #> 5  e 1 1 5 5  # switching values is also possible e.g. by moving from a to b and b to a. df_mov <- move_row_values(df,   select_rows = c(FALSE, FALSE, TRUE),   from_col = c("a", "b"), to_col = c("b", "a"), clear_value = NA ) df_mov #>   id  a b c d #> 1  a  5 5 1 1 #> 2  b  4 4 2 2 #> 3  c NA 3 3 2 #> 4  d  2 2 4 4 #> 5  e  1 1 5 5

what: Re-convert character columns in existing data frame — reguess_coltypes
title: Re-convert character columns in existing data frame — reguess_coltypes
text: Convenience wrapper around all_decimal_points_to_dot() readr::type_convert(). Optionally converts numeric-like characters comma decimal point (used e.g. Germany) dots, performs re-guessing column types character columns.

title: Re-convert character columns in existing data frame — reguess_coltypes
code: reguess_coltypes(df, convert_comma_to_dot = FALSE, silent = TRUE, ...)

title: Re-convert character columns in existing data frame — reguess_coltypes
text: df data.frame tibble character columns class shall re-guessed. convert_comma_to_dot Shall numeric-like characters comma decimal point like '1,2' converted '1.2' column type guessing? silent Suppress column specification message readr::type_convert() column type guessing. ... Arguments passed readr::type_convert col_types One NULL, cols() specification, string. See vignette("readr") details. NULL, column types imputed using rows. na Character vector strings interpret missing values. Set option character() indicate missing values. trim_ws leading trailing whitespace (ASCII spaces tabs) trimmed field parsing ? locale locale controls defaults vary place place. default locale US-centric (like R), can use locale() create locale controls things like default time zone, encoding, decimal mark, big mark, day/month names. guess_integer TRUE, guess integer types whole numbers, FALSE guess numeric type numbers.

title: Re-convert character columns in existing data frame — reguess_coltypes
text: similar object df, column types potentially changed.

title: Re-convert character columns in existing data frame — reguess_coltypes
code: # create data frame of characters df <- data.frame(a = c(1, 2, 3), b = c(TRUE, FALSE, NA), c = factor(c(1, 2, 1))) |>   all_to_character() df #>   a     b c #> 1 1  TRUE 1 #> 2 2 FALSE 2 #> 3 3  <NA> 1  reguess_coltypes(df) #>   a     b c #> 1 1  TRUE 1 #> 2 2 FALSE 2 #> 3 3    NA 1  # convert column b to numeric if convert_comma_to_dot is set. df <- data.frame(a = c("a,b", "1,b", "c,0"), b = c("1,1", "1,2", "1,3")) reguess_coltypes(df, convert_comma_to_dot = TRUE) #>     a   b #> 1 a,b 1.1 #> 2 1,b 1.2 #> 3 c,0 1.3

title: Relocate multiple columns — relocate_multi
text: Re-position multiple data frame columns . Extended wrapper around dplyr::relocate() support relocation multiple columns multiple respective positions .

title: Relocate multiple columns — relocate_multi
code: relocate_multi(df, move = NULL, before = NULL, after = NULL)

title: Relocate multiple columns — relocate_multi
text: df data.frame tibble columns shall relocated. move columns shall moved. Can column names, indices, <tidy-select> <data-masking> expressions. columns, respective move column shall placed . Can column names, indices, <tidy-select> <data-masking> expressions. columns, respective move column shall placed . Can column names, indices, <tidy-select> <data-masking> expressions.

title: Relocate multiple columns — relocate_multi
text: df re-positioned columns.

title: Relocate multiple columns — relocate_multi
text: column (selection) indices converted names, allow multiple relocation operations column without index confusion.

title: Relocate multiple columns — relocate_multi
code: df <- data.frame("a" = 1:2, "b" = 3:4, "c" = 5:6, "d" = 7:8) df #>   a b c d #> 1 1 3 5 7 #> 2 2 4 6 8  # Move column "a" after "b" and column "c" after "d" relocate_multi(df, move = c("a", "c"), after = c("b", "d")) #>   b a d c #> 1 3 1 7 5 #> 2 4 2 8 6  # The same operation with indices relocate_multi(df, move = c(1, 3), after = c(2, 4)) #>   b a d c #> 1 3 1 7 5 #> 2 4 2 8 6  # The same operation with tidy-select expression df |> relocate_multi(move = tidyselect::all_of(c(1, 3)), after = tidyselect::all_of(c(2, 4))) #>   b a d c #> 1 3 1 7 5 #> 2 4 2 8 6  # Use data masking to move "b" before "a" df |> relocate_multi(move = rlang::expr(b), before = rlang::expr(a)) #>   b a c d #> 1 3 1 5 7 #> 2 4 2 6 8  # Relocation operations are sequential: # Move "c" after "d" -> abdc # Move "a" after "c" -> bdca # Move "a" after "d" -> bdac relocate_multi(df, move = c("c", "a", "a"), after = c("d", "c", "d")) #>   b d a c #> 1 3 7 1 5 #> 2 4 8 2 6

title: Strip html tags — remove_html
text: Strip html tags vec potentially stringr::str_squish() remove excessive newlines whitespace.

title: Strip html tags — remove_html
code: remove_html(vec, squish = TRUE)

title: Strip html tags — remove_html
text: vec Character vector html tags shall removed . squish excessive newlines whitespace shall removed stripped text. Uses stringr::str_squish().

title: Strip html tags — remove_html
text: character vector without html tags.

title: Strip html tags — remove_html
code:
text <- "text with

some tags

" text #> [1] "text with

some tags

" remove_html(text) #> [1] "text with some tags"

title: NA-aware str_c — str_c_na
text: NA-aware drop-replacement str_c(). Discards NAs strings present. Reduces multiple NAs single one.

title: NA-aware str_c — str_c_na
code: str_c_na(..., sep = "", collapse = NULL)

title: NA-aware str_c — str_c_na
text: ... One character vectors. NULLs removed; scalar inputs (vectors length 1) recycled common length vector inputs. Like R functions, missing values "infectious": whenever missing value combined another string result always missing. Use dplyr::coalesce() str_replace_na() convert desired value. sep String insert input vectors. collapse Optional string used combine output single string. Generally better use str_flatten() needed behaviour.

title: NA-aware str_c — str_c_na
text: collapse = NULL (default) character vector length equal longest input. collapse string, character vector length 1.

title: NA-aware str_c — str_c_na
code: vec <- c("a", NA, "b")  # only returns NA stringr::str_c(vec) #> [1] "a" NA  "b"  # discards NA str_c_na(vec) #> [1] "a" NA  "b"  # collapse also discards NAs str_c_na(c("a", NA), c(NA, "b"), collapse = ", ") #> [1] "a, b"

what: Summarize outlier values for numeric vectors — summarize_outlier
title: Summarize outlier values for numeric vectors — summarize_outlier
text: Utilize check_outliers() determine values determined outliers. Summarizes result comma-separated, decreasing string. Allows specify minimal amount unique values vec perform outlier detection.

title: Summarize outlier values for numeric vectors — summarize_outlier
code: summarize_outlier(   vec,   minimal_unique_values = 10,   method = c("iqr", "zscore_robust"),   threshold = list(zscore_robust = 7, iqr = 5) )

title: Summarize outlier values for numeric vectors — summarize_outlier
text: vec vector checked outliers. minimal_unique_values Amount unique values vec outlier detection performed. Set 1 always perform detection. method outlier detection method(s). Can "" "cook", "pareto", "zscore", "zscore_robust", "iqr", "ci", "eti", "hdi", "bci", "mahalanobis", "mahalanobis_robust", "mcd", "ics", "optics" "lof". threshold list containing threshold values method (e.g. list('mahalanobis' = 7, 'cook' = 1)), observation considered outlier. NULL, default values used (see 'Details'). numeric value given, used threshold method run. EFA/PCA/Omega, indicates threshold correlation residuals (default, 0.05).

title: Summarize outlier values for numeric vectors — summarize_outlier
text: summary string outliers, empty string outliers detected.

title: Summarize outlier values for numeric vectors — summarize_outlier

what: Summarize metrics of a data.frame or tibble — summarize_table
title: Summarize metrics of a data.frame or tibble — summarize_table
text: Summarize metric every column df. Collects basic metrics, can also extend custom summary functions (custom_funs). Optionally detects culprits outliers.

title: Summarize metrics of a data.frame or tibble — summarize_table
code: summarize_table(   df,   custom_funs = list(),   find_culprits = TRUE,   find_outliers = TRUE,   find_outlier_opts = list() )

title: Summarize metrics of a data.frame or tibble — summarize_table
text: df 'data.frame' 'tibble'. custom_funs named list custom summary functions. find_culprits Shall culprit detection performed via find_culprit()? find_outliers Shall outlier detection performed via summarize_outlier()? find_outlier_opts find_outliers, specify named list non-default options summarize_outlier() call.

title: Summarize metrics of a data.frame or tibble — summarize_table
text: summary tibble many rows df columns.

what: Selectively suppress messages, warnings, cat and print — suppress_matching
title: Selectively suppress messages, warnings, cat and print — suppress_matching
text: Selectively suppress messages, warnings, cat /print whose output matches given regex pattern.

title: Selectively suppress messages, warnings, cat and print — suppress_matching
code: suppress_matching(   expr,   pattern = NULL,   suppress_messages = TRUE,   suppress_warnings = TRUE,   suppress_cat_print = TRUE,   ... )

title: Selectively suppress messages, warnings, cat and print — suppress_matching
text: expr expression potentially produces output. pattern Provide regex-string suppress matching output. NULL, suppresses output. suppress_messages output message() shall suppressed. suppress_warnings output warning() shall suppressed. suppress_cat_print output cat() print() shall suppressed. ... Arguments passed base::grepl ignore.case logical. FALSE, pattern matching case       sensitive TRUE, case ignored matching. perl logical.  Perl-compatible regexps used? fixed logical. TRUE, pattern string     matched .  Overrides conflicting arguments. useBytes logical.  TRUE matching done     byte--byte rather character--character.  See     ‘Details’.

title: Selectively suppress messages, warnings, cat and print — suppress_matching
text: return value expr.

title: Selectively suppress messages, warnings, cat and print — suppress_matching
text: Utilizes grepl() matching output given regex pattern. Selective suppression cat() print() tricky, differentiation single output trivial. function applies simple heuristic least separate print() output cat(). Two consecutive cat() outputs can differentiated moment, potentially leading unwanted selective suppression behavior.

title: Selectively suppress messages, warnings, cat and print — suppress_matching
code: noisy_fun <- function() {   message("I am a message")   warning("I am a warning")   cat("I am a cat")   print("I am a print")   return(TRUE) }  # suppress all result <- suppress_matching(noisy_fun())  # suppress by matching regex result <- suppress_matching(noisy_fun(), pattern = ".*am A.*", ignore.case = TRUE)

what: Transpose a data.frame or tibble — tidy_t
title: Transpose a data.frame or tibble — tidy_t
text: Allow transposing data.frame tibble "tidy" way. Instead row names, column names transposed object taken specified id_col. Note: input df contain row names, discarded.

title: Transpose a data.frame or tibble — tidy_t
code: tidy_t(   df,   id_col = 1,   exclude_cols = NULL,   new_id_colname = NULL,   reguess_coltypes = FALSE,   name_repair = "unique",   verbose = FALSE )

title: Transpose a data.frame or tibble — tidy_t
text: df --transposed data.frame tibble. id_col column df shall used new column names? Can either index column name. exclude_cols Exclude specified columns transposing. Can either one multiple indices column names, NULL. new_id_colname Rename first column transposed object. NULL, carry selected id_col column name. reguess_coltypes Shall re-guessing column types performed transposing? Allows correctly retrieve e.g. numeric logical columns utilizing reguess_coltypes(). name_repair Choose strategy potentially repair 'id_col', e.g. uniqueness. passed vctrs::vec_as_names(), supporting among else following strategies: "minimal": name repair checks, beyond basic existence names replacing NA's. "unique": Make sure names unique empty. suffix appended duplicate names make unique. "universal": Make names unique syntactic, meaning can safely use names variables without causing syntax error. verbose Set verbosity potential name_repair.

title: Transpose a data.frame or tibble — tidy_t
text: transposed object - keeps object type df input (data.frame tibble).

title: Transpose a data.frame or tibble — tidy_t
code: df <- data.frame(a = c("x1", "1", "FALSE"), b = c("x2", "2", "TRUE")) df #>       a    b #> 1    x1   x2 #> 2     1    2 #> 3 FALSE TRUE  tidy_t(df) #>   a x1 1 FALSE #> 1 b x2 2  TRUE  # reguessing column types tidy_t(df, reguess_coltypes = TRUE) #>   a x1 1 FALSE #> 1 b x2 2  TRUE  # using second column as id column tidy_t(df, id_col = "b") #>   b x2 2  TRUE #> 1 a x1 1 FALSE  # excluding columns tidy_t(df, exclude_cols = "b") #> [1] a     x1    1     FALSE #> <0 rows> (or 0-length row.names)  # renaming id column tidy_t(df, new_id_colname = "var") #>   var x1 1 FALSE #> 1   b x2 2  TRUE

what: Try conversion to date representation — try_date
title: Try conversion to date representation — try_date
text: Try conversion date serial value respective date representation. Return date object character representation conversion succeeds, original value . Allows convert dates /min/max date.

title: Try conversion to date representation — try_date
code: try_date(   x,   origin = c("excel", "excel_off1", "excel_1904", "unix"),   min_date = NULL,   max_date = NULL,   return_character = TRUE )

title: Try conversion to date representation — try_date
text: x single atomic value, .e. one string, number element. origin origin serial value, .e. day 0. See description list supported options. min_date Set minimum date conversion. Use format YYYY-MM-DD. max_date Set maximum date conversion. Use format YYYY-MM-DD. return_character Return character representation converted object, rather date object. affect return unsuccessful conversions. Returns Format YYYY-MM-DD.

title: Try conversion to date representation — try_date
text: Potentially date representation x, x otherwise.

title: Try conversion to date representation — try_date
text: Origin: Correct conversion relies correct origin serial value. Available options : excel: Set origin 1899-12-30. default date origin Excel Windows Mac since 2011. excel_off1: Set origin 1899-12-31. might useful tackle Excel's 1900 Leap Year Bug dates 28th February 1900. excel_1904: Set origin 1904-01-01. date origin Excel 1904 date system, default early versions Excel Mac. unix: Set origin 1970-01-01. Epoch time used unix-based systems. details date origin used Excel, see Microsoft.

title: Try conversion to date representation — try_date
code: # Excel has converted a date to a serial number, e.g. 40729  # convert to date representation try_date("40729") #> [1] "2011-07-05" try_date(40729) #> [1] "2011-07-05"  # no conversion for incompatible data types try_date("hello") #> [1] "hello" try_date("1900-01-01") #> [1] "1900-01-01"  # set min or max date to only convert values in range try_date("40729", min_date = "2011-07-06") #> [1] "40729"

what: Try conversion to date representation — try_dates
title: Try conversion to date representation — try_dates
text: Wrapper around try_date() multiple values. Try conversion date serial values respective date representation.

title: Try conversion to date representation — try_dates
code: try_dates(vec, ...)

title: Try conversion to date representation — try_dates
text: vec Vector containing values try conversion. ... Arguments passed try_date origin origin serial value, .e. day 0. See description list supported options. min_date Set minimum date conversion. Use format YYYY-MM-DD. max_date Set maximum date conversion. Use format YYYY-MM-DD.

title: Try conversion to date representation — try_dates
text: character vector potentially converted dates.

title: Try conversion to date representation — try_dates
text: Origin: Correct conversion relies correct origin serial value. Available options : excel: Set origin 1899-12-30. default date origin Excel Windows Mac since 2011. excel_off1: Set origin 1899-12-31. might useful tackle Excel's 1900 Leap Year Bug dates 28th February 1900. excel_1904: Set origin 1904-01-01. date origin Excel 1904 date system, default early versions Excel Mac. unix: Set origin 1970-01-01. Epoch time used unix-based systems. details date origin used Excel, see Microsoft.

title: Try conversion to date representation — try_dates
code: serial_values <- c(10000, 20000, 30000)  # convert with minimal date set - first value is not converted try_dates(serial_values, min_date = "1950-01-01") #> [1] "10000"      "1954-10-03" "1982-02-18"

title: Try conversion to numeric — try_numeric
text: Try conversion input element numeric. Return numeric representation succeeds, initial value .

title: Try conversion to numeric — try_numeric
code: try_numeric(x)

title: Try conversion to numeric — try_numeric
text: x single atomic value, .e. one string, number element.

title: Try conversion to numeric — try_numeric
text: Potentially numeric representation x, x otherwise.

title: Try conversion to numeric — try_numeric
code: # convert string representation of a number try_numeric("5") #> [1] 5 try_numeric("1e5") #> [1] 1e+05 try_numeric("Inf") #> [1] Inf  # also converts logicals try_numeric(TRUE) #> [1] 1  # does not alter elements without proper representation try_numeric("one") #> [1] "one" try_numeric(NA) #> [1] NA try_numeric(NULL) #> NULL

title: datatriage (development version)
text: Initial first release.
